intro: Chaetothylax haughtii, commonly known as the Haught's thistle, is a species of flowering plant in the Asteraceae family. It is native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico, where it thrives in arid and semi-arid environments. The plant is characterized by its spiny, leafy stems and purple to pinkish flowers that bloom in late summer. Its leaves are typically lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, contributing to its drought-resistant adaptations. The plant plays a role in local ecosystems by providing food and habitat for various insects and small animals.
